citations.narrative:
At the east side of the camel enclosure, there was an approximately 6 ft. section of loose wire fencing along the bottom
with some pointed wire ends. A dividing wire fence panel within the camel’s shelter structure has detached from the top
portion of its support post resulting in an approximately 5ft.section of loose, unstable and unsupported fencing.
Additionally, there were three exposed nails along the bottom of the west side of the camel’s shelter structure. Housing
facilities in disrepair including those with loose fencing, sharp wires or nails may lead to animal injury. Housing facilities
must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the
animals.
Correct by 02/06/2026.

The east side enclosure housing two camels did not provide sufficient shade for the number of housed animals. There
was a shade structure present in the enclosure; however, at time of inspection, this structure was not large enough to
adequately provide enough shade to comfortably protect both animals from direct sunlight. Outdoor enclosures with
inadequate shade may cause overheating or discomfort of the animals. Sufficient shade by natural or artificial means
must be provided to all animals kept outdoors to protect themselves from the direct sunlight.
Correct by 02/13/2026.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
At the east side of the camel enclosure, there was an approximately 6 ft. section of loose wire fencing along the bottom 
with some pointed wire ends. A dividing wire fence panel within the camel’s shelter structure has detached from the top 
portion of its support post resulting in an approximately 5ft.section of loose, unstable and unsupported fencing. 
Additionally, there were three exposed nails along the bottom of the west side of the camel’s shelter structure. Housing 
facilities in disrepair including those with loose fencing, sharp wires or nails may lead to animal injury. Housing facilities 
must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the 
animals. 
 
Correct by 02/06/2026. 
3.127(a) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The east side enclosure housing two camels did not provide sufficient shade for the number of housed animals. There 
was a shade structure present in the enclosure; however, at time of inspection, this structure was not large enough to 
adequately provide enough shade to comfortably protect both animals from direct sunlight. Outdoor enclosures with 
inadequate shade may cause overheating or discomfort of the animals. Sufficient shade by natural or artificial means 
must be provided to all animals kept outdoors to protect themselves from the direct sunlight. 
 
Correct by 02/13/2026. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
